qas.question: In addition to being used to build things, what has wood been used for over thousands of years?
What kind of strong fibers are part of the composite of wood?
What's the matrix in wood made up of?
What one word describes the function wood provides to a tree or plant?
What does wood convey to leaves, roots, and other tissues of a woody plant in addition to water?

context: It has been used for thousands of years for both <a0_0>fuel<a0_0/> and as a construction material. It is an organic material, a natural composite of <a1_0>cellulose<a1_0/> fibers (which are strong in tension) embedded in a matrix of <a2_0>lignin<a2_0/> which resists compression. Wood is sometimes defined as only the secondary xylem in the stems of trees, or it is defined more broadly to include the same type of tissue elsewhere such as in the roots of trees or shrubs.[citation needed] In a living tree it performs a <a3_0>support<a3_0/> function, enabling woody plants to grow large or to stand up by themselves. It also conveys water and <a4_0>nutrients<a4_0/> between the leaves, other growing tissues, and the roots. Wood may also refer to other plant materials with comparable properties, and to material engineered from wood, or wood chips or fiber.
